ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Much stronger understanding of Russian grammatical concepts and proficiency when speak/listening
My Russian reading, speaking and writing skills all improved substantially. Conjugation and aspect practice in conversational contexts was a big focus.
Review of concepts from first year, but in more detail. Relationship topics, sickness/health topics, lots of verbs of motion (for better or worse).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor and TA are very flexible and willing to work outside of class hours. Course material is entirely a review of previous material learned in L1 and L2, and the textbook material is only taught up to  4. 
Weaknesses: RUSS 130 is less structured than RUSS 110 and RUSS 120.
A bit unorganized, especially with homework and exam schedules. But the environment is very supportive, the professor is always willing and eager to help, and the material is so fun and exciting

Irina Andreevna is a wonderful professor, she is the driving force behind the course's quality and dynamism. I came to class everyday excited to learn Russian because she and John (my TF) helped cultivate a really great environment I felt comfortable speaking in.

Strengths: meets every day, amazing instructor, not too challenging or too much workload but you still learn a lot. I heard Irina may be gone after this year but Ilia and Anastasia are also excellent, you can't go wrong with any of them. Would've loved more readings and feedback on those but that's a very small complaint.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. If you are looking to continue learning Russian, this course provides the materials and assistance necessary. Additionally, this course goes at a slower pace than L1 and L2 Russian classes (or perhaps you've gotten over the larger learning curve of the russian language)

I would recommend this course. The material isn't particularly challenging at this point in learning the Russian language, but as it is a language course the workload is still high--comparable to L1 and L2.
1000%. If you need a language credit, take russian. Its challenging but so so so rewarding. Irina Andreevna is one of the best and kindest professors at Yale

I would in a heartbeat, the Russian department is amazing and Irina Andreevna is a great professor. Classes were informative, interactive, and full of opportunities to engage with the language. Feedback was given often and clearly. I have no complaints.
Yes! Most people will be just taking it for the L3 credit and dropping after this semester, but I think Russian is a lot of fun and worth learning just for the sake of it!
